The movie is actually quite boring up until the very end when the overwhelming anticipation gets the best of you.  Keifer Sutherland has a small part in the movie, and he is one of the better actors out there.  As for Kirsten Dunst, she has always had a rocking body and is not afraid to show it on this film.  Desperate nudity to draw your eyes to the screen of a very slow paced film??  I will let you decide. A/V-10---M-4

I logged on as a member of the Bay specifically so I could defend this film. I think people that are most used to Hollywood films will not have the capacity to understand it. European film is often much more demanding to understand. Look up the film on Wikipedia to get an understanding of the slightly eccentric plot - follow the links to 'Tristran and Isolda' to understand how the story links into this classic Wagner opera. Go to you tube to hear the prelude to the opera (how it is unresolved) and then listen to the 'death of isolde' to hear how the music resolves at the very end of the opera and get an idea of how the deaths of Wagner's characters link into the death of the planets in the film - and to the death of Justine's depression in the film. That death is the only way that Wagner believed love can be concreted and concecrated. The planets seem to kiss as they destroy each other. Believe me with some effort this film is really beautiful and deep... The accents are American, but only because these substantial actors have such faith in an amazing European (Danish) director... an for good reason... Science fiction at it's very best...

Lars Von Trier has a different way of telling a story.
The look and feel of the movie are pretty bleak, and slow.
I highly recommend skipping this movie if you have short attention span, or if you're American.

I'm American, and I really much enjoyed this film.
It's certainly not for everyone.
